Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from my mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Let us know how you’re doing.” I know she worries if I don’t check in, so I start typing a quick reply. Just then, my girlfriend, Emma, walks in, her face tense. “Can we talk about what happened with the dinner plans?” she asks, her voice tight. I remember the mix-up—she thought I’d canceled on her parents, but I’d just forgotten to confirm. She’s clearly upset, and I know she expects me to talk it through and make things right. My phone vibrates again—another message from my mom, this time asking if I’m eating well. I feel pulled in two directions: my parents want reassurance that I’m okay, but Emma needs my full attention to resolve our misunderstanding. My thumbs hover over my phone, my mind racing, heart pounding, as I try to figure out who needs me more in this moment.
